lastPostContent: Continuing our #BuildInPublic journey for `aattaran/tiktok`! This week, a big win for UI: we've standardized our form handling with `react-hook-form` & `yup`. Type-safe, robust forms are now default!

analyzedFeatures.name: Chrome Extension Architecture (tikko-ext-main)
analyzedFeatures.description: The `tikko-ext-main` directory represents a Chrome extension. It utilizes `vite` as a build tool, explicitly configuring rollupOptions for multi-entry-point builds to generate separate files for the background service worker and popup UI. The manifest.json defines permissions, host permissions, and externally_connectable origins, indicating interaction with specific websites.

analyzedFeatures.name: Shared UI Component Styling with Tailwind CSS
analyzedFeatures.description: Both `tikko-main` and `tikko-ext-main` projects utilize Tailwind CSS for styling. They extend the default Tailwind configuration with custom font families, colors, screen sizes, and box shadows. This suggests a consistent design language across both the main application and the Chrome extension.

analyzedFeatures.name: React Hook Form and Yup Integration
analyzedFeatures.description: Both projects leverage `react-hook-form` for form management and `yup` for schema validation. The `@hookform/resolvers` library is used to integrate Yup's schema validation with React Hook Form's form state management. This combination provides a robust and type-safe approach to form handling.

analyzedFeatures.name: API interaction using Axios
analyzedFeatures.description: The packages mention the axios package. It is used for making HTTP requests. This suggests the application will interact with a backend or external API endpoints to fetch or send data.

postedFeatures: Shared UI Component Styling with Tailwind CSS
React Hook Form and Yup Integration
